definitions.example: The Princess brought grace to an otherwise dull and boring party.

definitions.definition: A short prayer of thanks before or after a meal.
definitions.example: It has become less common to say grace before having dinner.

definitions.definition: In the games of patience or solitaire: a special move that is normally against the rules.

definitions.example: The dancer moved with grace and strength.

definitions.definition: An allowance of time granted to a debtor during which he or she is free of at least part of his normal obligations towards the creditor.
definitions.example: The repayment of the loan starts after a three-year grace.

definitions.definition: Free and undeserved favour, especially of God; unmerited divine assistance given to humans for their regeneration or sanctification, or for resisting sin.
definitions.example: I’m so grateful to God for the grace that He has given me.

definitions.definition: An act or decree of the governing body of an English university.
To adorn; to decorate; to embellish and dignify.
definitions.example: He graced the room by simply being there.

definitions.definition: To dignify or raise by an act of favour; to honour.
To add grace notes, cadenzas, etc., to.
